Award.AwardTitle: CC* Storage: The South Dakota Data Store, a Modular, Affordable Platform to Enable Data-Intensive Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Expanding opportunities for data-driven research and increasing requirements for data management in sponsored research have resulted in a growing need for retention of both long-term archival data sets that are infrequently accessed, as well as 'active archives' of data that are accessed periodically to revisit, revise, and share experimental results. For this project, the University of South Dakota will acquire, deploy, and maintain the South Dakota Data Store (SDDS), a network-accessible, sharable, multi-campus storage resource integrated with existing campus cyberinfrastructure. Initially, SDDS will support twelve STEM projects across eight departments at four institutions in South Dakota, including 30 faculty, 43 postdocs, and 303 students. SDDS will provide South Dakota researchers with a centralized, efficient, high-performance platform for both archival of and shared access to large quantities of electronic data.

SDDS includes two major services. The Sharing Tier provides high-reliability, high-availability, network-accessible storage for research requiring persistent access to large quantities of data. The Archival Tier provides long-term offsite archival-grade storage. SDDS will serve all faculty, staff, postdocs, students, and graduate students at the University of South Dakota. Through a partnership of multiple institutions, SDDS will also serve researchers at South Dakota State University, Black Hills State University, and the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, with access open to further community adoption by all educational and not-for-profit noncommercial researchers. The project leverages prior investments at the University of South Dakota and South Dakota State University in dedicated Science DMZ networks. All participants will be able to access SDDS via existing 10Gb connectivity, and end-to-end performance measurement is ensured using existing PerfSONAR deployments at all involved institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Expanding opportunities for data-driven research and increasing requirements for data management in sponsored research have resulted in a growing need for retention of both long-term archival data sets that are infrequently accessed, as well as 'active archives' of data that are accessed periodically to revisit, revise, and share experimental results. 

The South Dakota Data Store (SDDS) addresses these needs by providing two major services. The Sharing Tier provides high-reliability, high-availability, network-accessible storage for research requiring persistent access to large quantities of data. The Archival Tier provides long-term off site archival-grade storage. The Sharing Tier consists of over 400TB of traditional disk-based storage (expandable to over 1PB) located on the USD main campus in Vermillion, SD. The Archival Tier consists of 1PB of magnetic tape (expandable to over 4.5 PB) stored in a robotic tape library at the USD Community College for Sioux Falls campus in Sioux Falls, SD. Both storage tiers are accessible via high-speed gridFTP data protocols orchestrated by the Globus data management platform.

SDDS supports over 50 STEM projects across multiple disciplines at four institutions in South Dakota and provides South Dakota researchers with a centralized, efficient, high-performance platform for both archival of and shared access to large quantities of electronic data. Examples of supported research efforts include: 

  • Studying the effects of human disturbance on grassland ecosystems in the context of climate change, specifically grassland and agro-ecosystems of Mongolia and Kazakhstan,  the Northern Great Plains, and Upper Midwest ecosystems. This requires long term data records which include satellite data-derived raster files, meteorological data, socio-economic data, and UAV data for validation.

  • Studying the recovery of hand movement following stroke and subsequent rehabilitation, including detailed analysis of reaching and grasping movements which are recorded and stored for analysis. Neuroimaging data sets include functional and structural scans examining questions of motor control, stroke recovery, post-traumatic stress disorder, and impulse control.

  • Protein structure and identification studies of electronic data generated from Liquid Chromatography Mass Spectrometry instrumentation.

In support of SDDS USD also hosted South Dakota’s first Data Carpentry workshop, held in coordination with the Midwest Big Data Hub, which instructed learners from across the state in best practices and tools for data management and analysis. An overview of SDDS is also presented at biannual advanced computing and data seminars for USD faculty, staff, and students.

Through this project the South Dakota Data Store has successfully become a modular, affordable platform to enable data-intensive research and education.
